Not mentioning something out of embarrassment can delay important diagnosis and treatment. Your doctor is bound by confidentiality. Be open and honest  it is the best thing for your health.

The big five for staying healthy:

1. Move your body  at least 30 minutes of activity most days
2. Eat real food  mostly plants, not too much, variety of colors
3. Sleep enough  7-9 hours, consistent schedule
4. Manage stress  find what works for you (exercise, meditation, hobbies, friends)
5. Avoid harmful substances  no smoking, limit alcohol

Bonus: stay hydrated, maintain social connections, get regular checkups, keep vaccinations current, practice good hygiene, wear sunscreen. Small consistent habits beat dramatic short-term changes every time.

Just because you feel better does not mean you should stop medication  especially not antibiotics (stopping early creates resistant bacteria), blood pressure meds (BP will rise again), antidepressants (need gradual tapering  sudden stop causes withdrawal), insulin and diabetes meds (blood sugar will spike), and many chronic disease medications.

If you think you no longer need a medication, discuss it with your doctor first. They will guide you on whether and how to safely stop. Some medications need to be reduced gradually, not stopped suddenly.

Keep your child home from school if they have: fever (100.4F or higher  stay home until fever-free 24 hrs without medication), vomiting or diarrhea (keep home 24 hrs after last episode), persistent cough that disrupts class, pink eye with discharge, rash (until doctor confirms not contagious), head lice (until treated). Mild sniffles without fever are usually OK for school. When in doubt, call your pediatrician. Always inform the school so they can watch for outbreaks.

Your pharmacist is a medication expert  use them! They can: explain how to take medications, check for drug interactions, suggest over-the-counter alternatives, give vaccines, advise on minor ailments, and answer questions your doctor did not have time for. For prescriptions: your doctor sends it electronically or you bring a paper script. Allow time for filling (15-30 min to hours). For refills: call ahead, use the pharmacy app, or set up auto-refill. Transfer prescriptions between pharmacies easily. Do not hesitate to ask your pharmacist anything  consultations are free!

Caring for a sick loved one: help them stay hydrated and fed (even small amounts), make sure they take medications on time, monitor symptoms and temperature, let them rest (sleep is healing), keep the environment clean and comfortable. Watch for warning signs that need medical attention: difficulty breathing, persistent high fever, confusion, inability to keep fluids down, or worsening condition.

For yourself as caregiver: wash hands frequently to avoid getting sick, take breaks, ask for help from others, do not neglect your own health. Caregiver burnout is real  your health matters too.

Common medical terms simplified:

Acute = sudden and short-term. Chronic = long-lasting. Benign = not harmful/not cancer. Malignant = cancerous. Inflammation = body swelling and redness response. Diagnosis = identifying the condition. Prognosis = expected outcome. Biopsy = tissue sample for testing. Edema = swelling from fluid. Hyper = too much. Hypo = too little. -itis = inflammation (bronchitis, arthritis). Stat = immediately. NPO = nothing by mouth. PRN = as needed.

Always ask your doctor to explain terms you do not understand  they should absolutely do that for you.

keywords: how much water should I drink
rules.response: Aim for about 8 cups (2 liters) daily, more if active, hot weather, pregnant, or breastfeeding. Dehydration signs: dark yellow urine (aim for light straw color), dry mouth, headache, dizziness, fatigue, decreased urination. Severe dehydration: rapid heartbeat, confusion, fainting  seek medical help. All fluids count  water, tea, milk, soup, foods with high water content (watermelon, cucumber, oranges). Coffee and tea count too despite mild diuretic effect. Carry a water bottle and sip throughout the day rather than gulping large amounts at once.

Sleep is when your body does most of its healing. Tips for sleeping when sick: elevate your head with extra pillows (helps congestion and acid reflux), use a humidifier for dry cough and congestion, keep a glass of water and tissues by the bed, take nighttime cold medicine before bed if needed (contains sleep aid), cool room temperature, hot shower before bed (steam clears airways), honey tea before sleep soothes throat. Do not fight the urge to nap during the day  your body is telling you it needs rest.

disclaimer: This is for educational information only, not medical advice. For medical concerns, consult a healthcare professional. In emergencies, call your local emergency number.
